documents.title: Track day basics
documents.content: A track day is a supervised session on a closed circuit. You ride in groups by pace (novice, intermediate, advanced). Bring a helmet, leathers or approved gear, and tape or remove mirrors and lights as per org rules.

documents.title: Racing line
documents.content: The racing line is the fastest path through a corner: outside to inside (apex) to outside. You brake in a straight line, turn in, hit the apex, then accelerate out. Late apex is used for tight corners or when you need to accelerate earlier onto a straight.

qa.q: What does BP mean in motorcycle riding?
qa.a: Body position. Leaning off the bike into the corner to help turn and keep the bike more upright.
Carrying a small amount of front brake into the turn after turn-in, then releasing gradually. It keeps the front loaded and can tighten the line.

qa.q: What is the apex of a corner?
qa.a: The point where the bike is closest to the inside of the corner—the tightest part of your line.
A quick stop in the pit lane without going to the garage—e.g. for fuel or a tire change—then back on track.

qa.q: What is a knee slider for?
qa.a: Protection and a reference: when it touches the pavement you know you are near the lean angle limit for that corner.
Track is live; racing or session is on. Go when it's your group.
A tight S-shaped section of track used to slow bikes before a straight or for variety.
Session stopped. Slow down, no passing, return to pit as directed.
Riding in the air pocket behind another bike to reduce drag and gain speed, often used before a pass.
A lap before the race or session to warm tires and get a final look at the track.

qa.q: What does 'pick up the bike' mean?
qa.a: Stand the bike up to vertical (or more) to finish the corner and get on the gas, reducing lean.

qa.q: What is a track day org?
qa.a: Organization that rents the circuit and runs the day: groups, briefings, flags, and rules.
